awd_titl_txt: Developing Quantitative Modeling Tools for Design and Performance Assessment of Integrated Water Management Systems: a U.S.-China Joint Research Project
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this project is to develop quantitative models and associated databases to characterize and evaluate water infrastructure systems of different configurations, and enable data-supported decision making tools for design and operation of integrated water management (IWM) systems. The research will address a critical technical barrier in adopting IWM systems by establishing a set of quantitative models for design and assessment of water infrastructure systems of various configurations over their lifetimes. 

Specifically, the project will 1) develop statistical network topology models at low computational cost to characterize and predict hydraulic performance of water infrastructure networks with different configurations; 2) Investigate the interdependency and dynamic interactions among water supply, storm water and wastewater networks in an IWM paradigm; 3) Assess potential human and ecosystem health risks based on the types of alternative water sources, reclamation technologies, and end uses; 4) Evaluate the suitability and sustainability of existing and emerging water treatment technologies for IWM systems of different scales using a life cycle and systems approach. The research plan builds upon complementary expertise of 8 participating researchers at several partner institutions, and leverages multiple ongoing projects and other resources. The  highly collaborative education and outreach plan includes: 1) development of web-based course modules that will initially be used in existing courses, and integrated into a complete web-based course to be taught at all partner institutions; 2) means for sharing data among research labs and with the scientific community as well as the general public; 3) training for utility operators, urban water planners, and high school science teachers; 4) engaging high school students from schools serving large population of under-represented minorities in research; 5) a faculty and student exchange program between U.S. and Chinese partner institutions. Implementation of the plan will train the next generation of water professionals through a highly multi-disciplinary, cross-culture program, and equip them with technical tools enabling urban water sustainability for cities of different size, and economic development status. This award is co-funded by the CBET Environmental Sustainability program and the Office of International Science and Engineering.

por.por_cntn:
The main research goal of this project was to build and test computer models of urban water systems, based on their real layouts, to enable predictions of system-wide performance when using sustainable water management technologies, like treatment of wastewater to drinking water. Models like these will help public water infrastructure effectively and efficiently adapt to ongoing and future water scarcity, where water from traditional sources like lakes, rivers, and groundwater fails to provide enough water for human needs. Three models were developed, tested with data from the City of Houston’s public water supply system, and published or submitted for publishing. All three models included using advanced technologies to treat wastewater into drinking water at existing wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs) before putting the treated water into the city water supply, an approach called direct potable water reuse (DPR). The first model compared different combinations of either using DPR technologies or not at nine WWTPs in Houston and was able to estimate predicted cost and energy consumption for the system for each theoretical combination. The second model used an algorithm to create a simplified backbone of the Houston water network to make the number of required calculations possible for an analysis of cost and energy of delivering water to specific water users in the network. It was run with different combinations of DPR at the WWTPs which also changed how much water was treated for reuse at each WWTP. The third model tested the resilience of the water network, or how well the system could operate in spite of a negative event breaking something, like a pump, a pipe, or untreated contamination of a water source.

The results of modeling Houston in all three made clear the importance of how the network is laid out, such as elevation changes and piping connections, in defining how use of DPR affects both local and system-wide performance. Importantly, all three models were able to predict these differences based on the design of the existing system, operating data from the City of Houston, and physics-based modeling of DPR. The first and second models’ results both predict that there are come combinations of DPR at Houston’s WWTPs which can result in reduced overall system cost and/or reduced overall system energy consumption. The third model’s results for Houston showed a slight increase in system resilience when using DPR at the WWTPs compared to the status quo and identified benefits and tradeoffs in resilience at the local and system levels based on the relative location and degree of piping connections to the rest of the network. Future use of these models will help set performance goals for advanced water treatment technologies and identify optimal places to use them to reduce cost and energy use and increase water quality at the system-wide level.

The results of the modeling research were shared with the City of Houston and presented at relevant research-oriented conferences. This project also supported collaboration with researchers at Tsinghua University in Beijing, China. The issue of urban water scarcity is global, and members of each university were able to learn from each others’ work.

A postdoctoral research associate, a PhD candidate, a PhD student, and an undergraduate from Rice University, who all conducted or contributed to the modeling research, were supported by the project in furthering their research careers through the associated publications and presentations. Three faculty members and two MS students at Tsinghua Universithy participated in the project as part of our international collaboration.
